G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The requested modification aligns with the principles outlined in G.L. c. 208, § 28, which allows the Court to modify custody orders upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the children’s best interests.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28A.proposition: This Court has proper jurisdiction over the parties and subject matter under G.L. c. 208, § 28A, as both parties and the minor children reside in Massachusetts.

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 495 (2012.proposition: The Court has held that in custody cases, the best interests of the children must be the paramount consideration.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 495 (2012.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in custody matters the core inquiry is what is best for the child, and it applies that standard in reviewing the custody determination. While phrased as the “touchstone inquiry” rather than “paramount consideration,” the substance is the same: the best interests of the child govern the custody decision and must guide the judge’s weighing of all relevant factors. Thus the case supports the proposition that the children’s best interests are paramount in custody cases.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 495 (2012.relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. See Commonwealth v. Beals, 405 Mass. 550, 554 (1989). ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] . . . what is “best for the child” . . . .’ Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003). ‘The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge . . . [whose] findings . . . “must stand unless they are plainly wrong.”’”}

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766-6.proposition: The Court has held that in custody cases, the best interests of the children must be the paramount consideration.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766-6.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the governing standard in terms of the child’s welfare and best interests, explaining that parental rights must yield to the welfare of the child and that the key inquiry is whether the parents are currently fit to further the child’s welfare and best interests. While much of the discussion is couched in terms of parental unfitness in care-and-protection and related proceedings, the court repeatedly links fitness to the child’s best interests, making clear that the child’s welfare/best interests are paramount in custody determinations. Thus, it provides support for the proposition that the best interests of the children must be the paramount consideration.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766-6.relevant_excerpt: “[T]he unfitness standard must be applied whenever the State seeks to terminate parents’ rights to the custody of their minor children…. Custody is not to be transferred from the natural parent simply because another prospective custodian is thought to be better qualified. … ‘State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.’ … In that sense, the fitness of parents and the best interests of the child are related. … ‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’”

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239, 244 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The Plaintiff is concerned for the children’s emotional and physical well-being, as well as their need for stability and routine.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The proposition is a factual assertion about this particular plaintiff’s concerns for the children’s emotional and physical well-being and their need for stability and routine. Schechter is a custody, abuse-prevention, removal, and prenuptial-agreement case; while it discusses the child’s best interests, domestic violence, and the importance of stability generally, it does not state that this plaintiff (in some other case) has such concerns. Thus it does not provide legal authority for that specific proposition.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, the judge made findings that the father was domineering in his relations with the mother and child… The judge also documented the father’s… lack of impulse control… The judge’s decision to suspend visitation for one year is also supported by his extensive findings that… the father had engaged in physical, emotional, and financial abuse of the mother, and, in his interactions with the child, had damaged the mother’s relationship with the child… [The mother] is committed to [the child], consistent in her parenting, and she provides [the child] with stability.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 262 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Any substitute caregiver used by the Defendant must be identified and approved in advance by the Plaintiff and/or the Court, consistent with the principles articulated in Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 262 (2001).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rosenthal v. Maney concerns modification of custody and a custodial parent’s request to relocate out of the Commonwealth. It does not address, establish, or even mention any rule requiring that substitute caregivers be identified and approved in advance by the other parent or the court. The discussion of third-party childcare is purely factual background and is not converted into a legal standard or condition on custody or visitation, so the case does not support the cited proposition.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “During the marriage as well as following the parties’ separation and divorce, the mother’s employment as a professional musician and private violin teacher (and, we assume, the father’s full-time employment) required the assistance of child-care providers other than the parents. Other than in Caleb’s first year, when childcare was provided by the father’s sister, childcare was provided primarily by the maternal grandmother, in addition to other family members and nonfamily caregivers.”

Guardianship of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 5.proposition: These proposed modifications are in the best interests of the children and are necessary to ensure their safety, stability, and emotional development.
Guardianship of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 5.support_reasoning: The case discusses the need for explicit findings on domestic violence and its effect on the child when determining custody and shared custody arrangements. It does not make or endorse any finding that a particular set of “proposed modifications” is in the best interests of the children or necessary for their safety, stability, or emotional development. Instead, the court reverses and remands for further findings; it does not hold that any specific modifications meet a best-interests or safety/stability/emotional-development standard.
Guardianship of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 5.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31.”
